channel.title: Learning russian
channel.description:
I want to learn russian because I want something to do. Has anyone here learned russian? i've heard its surprisingly easier than expected, especially because most words are spelled exactly how they sound, and there is a letter for every sound in the language, like ch, sh, and "z" in vision.
I have a friend who is willing to learn with me (who is really interested in other languages) so itd be great to talk back and forth to eachother with complete fluidity for privacy.
What are the best techniques for learning a language (those of you who have) obviously memorization isn't the best way to learn at all, ive heard contextual learning is the most logical way and its how our brain learned english in the first place.
We learned by words we've never heard before being plugged into context with a native sentence. Like "Можно (mohzh-na) go to the bathroom?" you learn Можно as "may i" and immediately remember with the word with the action rather than translating it in your head first.
So what are peoples views of learning languages?
ps I wanted to learn finnish but supposedly its harder than Russian. Dutch and German are apparently the easiest for english speakers to learn but they dont have the most awesome fucking alphabet in the world.

item.title: Learning russian
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Frell:

Why does there have to be a motive? Why cant I learn a language just to have credit for knowing that language? Tons of people here know English and Spanish because they’re the only two languages that are seen. To be able to say you speak Norwegian or Russian really stands out on your resume (although it isnt useful) youll stand out from the crowd. Why did he need to learn ______? No reason. Did he go out of his way to do it? He did.

I’m not saying that a motive is an absolute necessity. But a motive or goal is something that will keep you motivated. As I said earlier, learning a language isn’t done overnight. You’re having fun now, but how will you feel in half a year, or a year? Will you still be as motivated?

I’m not trying to persuade you not to learn a new language. I admire your willingness to gather knowledge and gain a new skill. But you have to realize that at some point, the progression slows down and you’ll get bored and frustrated. At that point, you need something to flip the switch and continue studying. Perhaps a better resume does the trick for you.
